Headline: Global stocks tumble on fears of U.S. recession and tech pullback.
Summary: The Nasdaq composite fell 3 43% and the Dow Jones plummeted more than 1,000 points, losing 2 6%. Apple had its worst day since September 2022, shedding 4 82%. President Joe Biden didn’t respond directly to Monday’s market panic, and instead released a statement touting his student loan forgiveness program and the expansion of college Pell grants. The sell-off began on Friday after the publication of the latest U S employment data, which showed fewer jobs were created in July than expected. This came only two days after the Federal Reserve opted to keep its benchmark interest rate steady at a two-decade high.Main European stocks index hit its lowest in over six months tonight. Energy and utility stocks at the forefront of a broad-based market slide. Australia's share market has suffered its worst day since the onset of the pandemic as fears of a US recession prompted investors to exit their positions. More than $100bn in value has been erased from local stocks, erasing $100billion in value. UK inflation holding steady at 2 0 percent in June from May, stronger than forecast, helped push the British pound close to a one-year high above $1 30.

Headline: Google's antitrust loss could put billions at risk for Apple, Yahoo Finance says.
Summary: District of Columbia's Judge Amit Mehta ruled in favor of the Department of Justice in its antitrust suit against the tech giant. The ruling could force Google to make dramatic changes to its largest business, but it could also force the company to cancel a long-term revenue-sharing agreement with Apple. The deal, called an Information Services Agreement, has been in place since 2002 and has been adjusted over the years as new technologies, such as the iPhone, have been introduced. Apple doesn't reveal exactly how much it makes from the deal, but court documents pegged the number at an estimated $20 billion in 2022.Shares in several major technology companies plunged Monday morning amid a wider sell-off in the market. Tesla opened 10 9 percent down, while Apple slid 9 6 percent, and Amazon fell 8 2 percent at the start of trading. Microsoft saw the least volatility out of the major tech stocks, falling 4 8 percent at market open Monday. The tech stocks’ steep slide Monday morning came as the wider market took a downturn amid growing concerns about a recession. Despite the current selloff, John Higgins, chief markets economist for Capital Economics, is skeptical that the AI-fueled market rally has ended.

Headline: X is closing San Francisco HQ and relocating staffers to San Jose and 'shared space'.
Summary: X CEO Linda Yaccarino said the office closure will occur ‘over the next few weeks’ She described the decision as ‘the right one for our company in the long term’ X’s departure from San Francisco represents a symbolic blow to the city, which has seen an exodus of tech firms from its once busy downtown area. Elon Musk recently stated that he would move the X and SpaceX headquarters from California to Texas. He cited a new California law banning school transgender notification requirements as his reason for leaving. The billionaire also slammed California for passing a student gender identity law. Musk has repeatedly clashed with local authorities since buying the company formerly known as Twitter for $44 billion in late 2022. X will also open an engineering-focused office in Palo Alto, Calif , which it will share with xAI, the artificial intelligence outfit owned by Mr Musk.

Headline: Dow plunges more than 1,000 points amid fears of U.S.
Summary: The S&P 500 slid 160 points, or 3%, to 5,186 on Monday, the index's biggest one-day drop in nearly two years. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite sank 3 4% as investors fled some of the Big Tech players that until recently had powered the US market higher. The market rout extended to Asian and European markets, with Japan's benchmark stock index plunging 12 4% on Monday. The Nikkei 225 index soared nearly 11% early Tuesday, a day after it set markets tumbling in Europe and on Wall Street. The yen hit a 7-month high against the dollar Monday as investors weighed the prospects for more aggressive Federal Reserve rate cuts against higher rates in Japan. The Labor Department reported Friday that the U S economy added only 114,000 jobs in July and the unemployment rate had jumped to 4 3%.

Headline: Palantir Ups Profit Outlook, Says AI Has ‘Transformed’ Business.
Summary: Palantir Technologies Inc’s stock jumped in extended trading after the company raised its annual outlook. The company increased its 2024 revenue guidance to a range of $2 74 to $2 75 billion. Palantir provides data analysis tools to companies and governments, including for defense and intelligence purposes. It was co-founded by billionaire Peter Thiel in 2003, and its software is now used across all branches of the U.S. military, and is involved in developing the country”s AI capabilities. The stock was up 40% this year through Monday’S close of $24.09 in the New York Stock Exchange's regular trading session, and about 13% after closing at $24 09 in the extended trading session. The former New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady is there as a fan, along with his daughter Vivian.

Headline: CrowdStrike says it isn't to blame for Delta's flight cancellations after July.
Summary: CrowdStrike shares have lost more than 36% of their value since the outages affected millions of computers. Delta canceled more than 5,000 flights between the July 19 outage, caused by a botched software update, through July 25. CrowdStrike claims it offered Delta assistance several times only to be rebuffed. The cybersecurity firm says Delta's lawsuit is 'meritless' and would prefer to work cooperatively with Delta to find a solution. Delta CEO Ed Bastian said last week the company had "no choice" but to seek damages for the losses incurred. Delta is now under investigation by the U S Department of Transportation's Office of Aviation Consumer Protection. The airline canceled more flights last month than they did in 2018 and 2019. Ryanair said it flew 20 2 million passengers in July, an 8% jump on the 18 7 million people on its flights the same time last year.

Headline: The value of AI chip start-up Groq rises to $2.8 billion.
Summary: Semiconductor startup Groq said on Monday it has raised $640 million in a Series D funding round. The financing round was led by investor BlackRock and attracted backing from investment funds of KDDI, Samsung and Cisco. Groq plans to use the funding to build about 108,000 language processing units, hire significantly and look at some acquisitions. The Series D round almost triples the Mountain View, California-based company’s valuation from $1 billion in a funding round in 2021. The AI chip market could reach $400 billion in annual sales in the next five years, according to some analysts. Nearly 92% of software-as-a-service (SaaS) startups in India have integrated some form of artificial intelligence (AI) features into their products. More than 150 companies have raised nearly $5 billion on India's booming stock market so far this year.

Headline: Buca di Beppo files for bankruptcy, plans to keep remaining 44 locations open.
Summary: Buca di Beppo, based in Orlando, Florida, announced Monday it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in the Northern District of Texas. The company said it intends to use the bankruptcy process to restructure its operations and keep 44 locations open, including restaurants in Pasadena, Universal City, Encino and Redondo Beach. It cited a significant drop in sales, rising food and labor costs, staffing challenges and changes in consumer preferences as the impetus behind the move. The privately held company, which was founded in Minneapolis in 1993, is opening one new location. Red Lobster said its remaining locations — about 580 in the U S and Canada, as well as franchise locations in a handful of other countries — would operate as usual. The Livonia Chicken Guy, metro Detroit’s first, shuttered in June after 15 months in business. Rubio's Coastal Grill closed 48 of its California restaurants, including 24 in the Los Angeles area.

Headline: The stock market selloff is about more than weak economic data, says Yahoo Finance.
Summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped more than 12% in its biggest-ever daily loss after a surprise interest rate hike from the Bank of Japan. Big Tech remained the main culprit of the sell-off, with Nvidia (NVDA) sliding more than 6% while Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT) were all off more than 3%. The S&P 500's losses cascaded nearly 3%. in its worst day since 2022. Wall Street's "fear gauge" touched its highest level since the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic.Systematic funds have offloaded more than $130 billion of global stock bets in recent weeks.OCBC’s plans for separately-listed GEH was again a point of contention at its AGM. OCBC will report its 1QFY2024 results on May 10 before trading opens.
